title: Before 30 April 2017, will the U.S. give notice of intent to withdraw from the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change?
preds: Not on his list of things that need immediate attention
Only 2 days left and no news of such a move.
I'm sure Trump will try, but not by Saturday.
Down on time elapsed and a statement from Trump
This is not a priority what with the shutdown and all.

State department memo released today closes the door on this possibility before the end of the month. https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.bloomberg.com/amp/politics/articles/2017-04-26/state-department-memo-boosts-case-to-stay-in-paris-climate-pact

While Trump certainly does love to talk about how climate change is a hoax invented by the Chinese, there's no way the United States will withdraw from the UNFCCC.  If he did, he would face enormous amounts of protest and opposition.  Additionally, Trump's focus has been mainly on trade negotiations, job creation and the Middle East.  I predict he will start to implement policy regarding climate change much later in his term, and certainly not by April 30th.
Too many other things on the agenda when this can be kicked down the road for at least another week.
Trump has too many fish to fry at this point. Even if he thought he could count it as a win for his first 100 days, he wouldn't have time or staff to even begin the process.

Lowering to 2% from 4%, given time remaining to close. The remaining option for this to resolve "yes" I can think of is if intention to withdraw is announced alongside the tax plan to be announced this week.

I've been reading that Trump plans a decision about this towards the end of May.  His advisors are not in agreement on this and an important meeting on climate change issues scheduled for Tuesday was cancelled, but now that everyone is talking about what Trump has done in his first 100 days, I'm wondering if he'll make a precipitous decision.  I don't think that the president can give notice; I think that the Senate must. But, I'm Increasing my forecast in case I've been wrong about everything.
Reduced from 5% to 1% based on news that Trump is postponing this week's meeting on this topic.
Apparently he is increasingly reluctant to do this - listening to the less strident advisors

No change from zero probability. April 18 article in New York Times says, "Mr. Trump plans to make a final decision on the fate of the Paris agreement before a meeting of the Group of 7 leading economies at the end of May, according to Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary."
Easier to control if staying in , could ask/demand concessions

Advisers to President Donald Trump will meet on Tuesday to discuss whether to recommend that he withdraw the United States from the Paris climate accord, a White House official said on Monday.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-climatechange-idUSKBN17J1DN
Too short a time frame. Potential political suicide.
With all the other things going on, now is not the time

Because Congress is in recess and the Senate would have to agree.
Because time is running out.
Because Trump has North Korea, China & Russia to deal with.

Decreasing to 1% because:
1) Coal companies would like to keep it in place so that the US can steer it in a way to benefit foreign exports.
2) The White House said they would make a decision by the end of May last week.
Update based on calendar, lack of discussion about this, and the news that some energy companies are lobbying the White House not to withdraw.

Trump is riding a bit of a bump from his Syria strike and getting Gorsuch confirmed. No reason why he'd cause an uproar over something like this, when he has effectively achieved this through Executive Order. But, then again, he does like find issues to distract the population with.
I can't see Trump moving on this issue anytime soon, he's preoccupied with domestic affairs (Trumpcare, Investment stimulus, FBI Investigation etc...)
It is 10 April. Clearly Trump has other issues on his agenda, so this has been pushed back.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-g20-growth-europe-idUSKBN17A0GA
21 days left in the period of interest and there have been no signs that this is a priority for the Administration,  which seems to have limited bandwidth for dealing with unrelated issues.

Dropping from seven to one because the administration is moving much slower on climate issues (yeah there was a show of trump signing some things that don't actually really mean anything) than I was expecting.
No need.  This one will be disregarded to death, at least by the US.  Lots of other states have not lost interest yet, by great good luck.

On the one hand, coal producing companies don't want to leave the Paris agreement (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-coal-idUSKBN1762YY). Also, many don't even expect his recent repeal of Obama's Clean Power Plan to remain for long enough to justify long-term investment (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-climate-power-idUSKBN1770D8).
On the other hand, though, it is one campaign promise he can keep. He has kept so few, so far, he might feel compelled to do it just to show some work. Still, the Trump administration only intends to provide an answer before the G7 Summit, which is after the 30th. So, whatever the decision, it may only happen after the question's deadline.
Plans to do this but not in time for a deadline
Not something that Trump needs to do, but you never know

Pres. Trump doesn't care about policy, he cares about optics, and he's already established a reputation as an environmental-regulation buster. I doubt this will happen in the time frame because he's already checked the "environmental deregulation" box on his list. Until we hear rumblings from the White House about the UNFCC *specifically*, I don't believe it will happen.

too many mistakes already done...will try to pospone a while this one
They will just ignore it. US already met 2020 standards.
The administration needs a win, and this isn't a priority with the other things going on (Gorsuch, FY17 budget/CR, etc.). Still, they can always surprise everyone with an announcement.
EO this week on climate policies mention almost everything BUT UN framework or Paris accord.

looks like the timetable the WH set for this is by the end of May, and since the have lots going on in April and have just signed the exec order on climate change this week, I think they're not going to feel the need to speed up their timetable. In their minds, they did a climate thing already.

No need to do this soon.  US cooperation with this effort is pretty much dead as of the other day, and existing international agreements do not exist in the mind, such as it is, of this president.

The Trump administration may try to appeal to some of its supporters on climate change issues, but with all the Trump team has on their plate, notice of withdraw from the UNFCCC before April 30 seems unlikely. Scientific evidence seems to be persuading many people who were previously on the fence about climate change. Related news articles:

While Trump might be desperate to achieve a campaign promise it seems that not all his team see the point of withdrawing from UNFCCC. Trump could try to link the UNFCCC to his stated objective of helping US coal miners, but it is not obvious that withdrawing from UNFCCC would boost coal mining while oil and gas are cheaper to use.
We had the travel bans, then healthcare and Keystone XL pipeline, now we move on to taxes, possibly followed by "The Wall".  Slim chance climate change will be addressed before 30 April.

I believe this is a viable avenue for advancing President Trump's environmental agenda. However, I'm increasingly suspicious because we haven't heard anything directly from the White House (either through above-board channels or leaked). If this were on President Trump's agenda, I suspect we'd know about it. Downgrading accordingly.
Trump focuses on what's in the news. This agreement hasn't been in the news, even when FOX news talks about the Paris Agreement. Hence, out of sight, out of mind.
There's more pressing, time-sensitive issues on the plates of Trump & Congress.

Most Americans believe climate change is real. They just don't think it directly affects them. I believe this is why so many are willing to weaken domestic environmental regulations in the hopes that they will lead to more jobs. However, when thinking about climate change in general, I suspect most Americans tend to adopt a "us vs. them" mentality, picturing smog-covered cities, polluted rivers, etc. I think support for withdrawing from a UN agreement will be less widespread.

While the administration is applying significant effort to dismantle climate science within the U.S. government, giving notice of intent to withdraw would continue diluting the direction of the Trump WH. However, if the Russia investigation begins to turn up significant evidence, or some other scandal breaks out that is particularly damaging to the administration, it's possible Trump could move forward on this as means to distract from such scandal. Whether there would be political support for such action remains to be seen.

I don't think Trump administration has decided what they're going to do about this. One issue is that the UNFCC was ratified by Congress, so Trump probably can't just unilaterally withdraw, if the mood strikes him. Trump could announce something, of course, but probably won't until he knows how he's going to proceed.

So far as I can tell, Pres. Trump hasn't made any public statements about the UNFCCC. In lieu of that insight, there are rumors (http://fortune.com/2016/11/14/donald-trump-paris-climate-change-deal/) that he may be considering withdrawing from the UNFCCC as an alternative to withdrawing from the Paris Accords, which can't legally happen until 2020. The rumor states that Trump is planning this within the next year. I give that rumor 90% confidence. 90% amortized over 3 blocks of time (the article is roughly one block of time old) is about 55% per block, and there is roughly one block until the end of April.

There appears to be little practical point to withdrawing from UNFCCC because it does not actually require the US to take any action on climate change. The Paris Agreement that the US recently ratified also does not commit the US to any specific action and as it requires giving 4 years notice would not be effective until after the next Presidential election. It would be possible to withdraw from the UNFCCC after giving a years notice, but as the UNFCCC has 196 other states and territories signed up withdrawing would put the USA in a very small club. Withdrawal could put the US in a difficult place going forward as it would be seen as a sign that the USA was withdrawing from all international bodies and becoming a closed country and might effect other international treaties. 
The only point to withdrawing would be to please some Trump supporters who probably don't know what the effects could be. He could probably please them just as much by saying he will ignore Climate Change.

While President Trump has made a point that he does not believe in climate change believes the UN is not effective and has loudly stated that he most certainly will have  the U.S.withdraw from the Paris Agreement, he will receive advice from Chief of Staff Reince Priebus,  likely Secretary of State designate Rex Tillerson, and possibly daughter Ivanka that the political blow back internationally would not be a worthwhile price to pay, particularly as he has other potential avenues of undermining climate change initiatives in the U.S. that would be less visible, at least in the short term.  I am revising my estimate downward to approximately 28 percent in line with two recent reductions in legislative oversight of the fossil fuel industies (coal, oil, natural gas) with many more to come.  These included deregulating oversight regulations for preventing coal mining, oil and natural gas dumping and contaminating streams and river, and the repeal of a regulation that would have required energy companies to disclose their payments to foreign governments.  The latter repeals a Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) rule written under the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform law meant to fight corruption in resource-rich countries by mandating that companies on United States stock exchanges disclose the royalties and other payments that oil, natural gas, coal and mineral companies make to governments.  Paradoxically, this trend pretty much negates a need to withdraw from the UN Framework as compliance is voluntary and Trump's actions eliminates the need for him to formally withdraw.  I believe that the current activity rate on other issues, such as moving ahead on infrastructure programs and ongoing immigration issues would tend to relegate abandoning the framework to well beyond the first hundred days.  I would go lower to 20 percent if I were as sure of the President's predictability as I am of the rationale for not withdrawing.  Revise prediction:  25%

To start with I assume this event is extremely unlikely because in general established policies have a lot of momentum behind them. As well, this question is about the 1994 framework treaty and not the Paris Treaty, which I think is more likely for Trump to announce a withdrawal from. That said, I think this is very unlikely to happen for a few reasons. First, Trump has focused entirely on the Paris agreement in his public comments and has shown no interest in looking further back. Second, he will have senior advisers (ie Tillerson and Ivanka) who believe in climate change and will be advising Trump to stick with existing agreements. Finally, it is far easier to simply not honor the convention instead of dealing with the public backlash against a formal withdrawal.

President-Elect Trump subscribes to the view, as do I, that the United Nations (UN) is a voluntary association of member nation-states.  Member nation-states in the UN do NOT give up their national sovereignty except insofar as they voluntarily sign and ratify treaties with other sovereign nation-states.  The UN is NOT any kind of "world government" and does not have any authority over its members except as they have allowed by signing and ratifying treaties.  When the UN attempts to exert influence that is clearly biased or against our national interests, then we, the United States, are under no obligation to follow those programs.  President-Elect Trump, I feel, believes that the UN is biased against the Western democracies.  With respect to climate change, the United States has done more to save and restore Earth's environment than China, Russia, India, and the great majority of the other member nations of the UN.  Yet the United States and the other Western democracies are supposed to take environmental measures that will cost them an enormous amount of money while China, India and Russia continue to pollute the air and water on a massive scale.   And, we're also supposed to pay a hugely disproportionate share of the overall costs of the UN, which takes every chance they can to criticize and condemn the U.S. and its allies.  I think President-Elect Trump shares these views in some measure, and it is therefore  more likely that the new administration might withdraw from this largely political framework on so-called "Climate Change".

Although Trump has disparaged global warming, I am unsure how much of a priority it is to him. His EPA director is a global warming denier and the Republican base wants to dismantle as much of the Obama legacy as possible as quickly as possible, Trump will have higher priorities. And to add a wrinkle, since Tillerson comes from the energy industry, slowing down this process might give him a chance to prove his credentials as one who is not beholden to his past interests. Maybe I am being optimistic, but for Tillerson to look the statesman might be inviting, although it will incur the wrath of the base.

This is a pretty big step, which will likely meet some bipartisan opposition in Congress, given that President George H.W. Bush put the US signature under the Convention in 1992. The rise of Donald Trump to power means a reverse on American strategy for the next decade. The US was making a smart shift from the old corrupt oil industry to renewable energy forcing unreformed autocracies from Russia to Middle Eastern or African countries to change politics. The main losers of this strategy, the Russian economy and American oilman have put their efforts together to get an outsider to the White House and go against the natural strategical interests of the US. The nomination of oil industry CEO's into high ranking positions and the early signs of the oil industry revamping stand proof to this assumption. Also, Donald Trump has proved a habit in not caring for US reputation when talking about revoking US prior commitments.

under the convention, the US, just like other countries, will have to finance action in less developed countries; in my view Mr Trump will use the threat to withdraw to obtain benefits to the US, such as collaboration on anti-terror or business alliances. Communicating earlier the withdrawal from the convention reinforces credibility of the threat and thus improves the bargaining position of the US. Despite diplomatic interdependencies against such a withdrawal, still likely to win, these considerations bring me to a 40% probability: still more likely that it will not happen, but more likely than the consensus on the matter.

The real issue seems to be the Paris Climate change agreement which requires 4 years to exit. This agreement did not require Congressional approval, as all specifications in the agreement are voluntary; and does not actually commit any country to anything specific. The GOP has determined that a faster way of exiting the non-binding agreement, would be to withdraw from the 1994 UNFCCC agreement signed by G. Bush.

Despite Trump's claims that China is behind this "hoax," China recently announced a multi-billion dollar plan to improve energy efficiency and decrease pollution, including coal. Most Americans, including many Republicans, agree that humans have affected our climate. As Trump attends more briefings, he will come to understand that climate change is not a partisan topic.

Trump has signaled malleability on the topic of climate change and it is certainly not within the category topics he is most passionate about. Withdrawal will have international costs that he will likely not wish to incur, climate change is broadly accepted by the American public (despite a vocal dissenting minority), and there are other things higher on his agenda that will require political capital. I don't see him messing around with this particular convention - and certainly not before April, only a few months into his administration.
